greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of necklace compositions of n with no part circularly followed by a divisor or a multiple.
comment: A necklace composition of n (A008965) is a finite sequence of positive integers summing to n that is lexicographically minimal among all of its cyclic rotations.
Circularity means the last part is followed by the first.
link: Andrew Howroyd, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..200
example: The a(5) = 1 through a(13) = 6 necklace compositions (empty column not shown):
program: b(n, q, pred)={my(M=matrix(n, n)); for(k=1, n, M[k, k]=pred(q, k); for(i=1, k-1, M[i, k]=sum(j=1, k-i, if(pred(j, i), M[j, k-i], 0)))); M[q,]}
seq(n)={my(v=sum(k=1, n, k*b(n, k, (i,j)->i%j<>0 && j%i<>0))); vector(n, n, sumdiv(n, d, eulerphi(d)*v[n/d])/n)} \\ _Andrew Howroyd_, Oct 26 2019
xref: The case forbidding divisors only is A328600 or A318729 (with singletons).
The non-necklace, non-circular version is A328508.
The version for co-primality (instead of indivisibility) is A328597.
results.author: _Gus Wiseman_, Oct 25 2019
ext: Terms a(26) and beyond from _Andrew Howroyd_, Oct 26 2019
